citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
According to the licensee, on May 21, 2025, a male emu was euthanized due to a severe unknown medical condition
affecting his ability to walk. The licensee did not convey this condition to the attending veterinarian for approximately three
months.
A juvenile male emu, “Arnold”, was purchased in Mid-February, 2025. The licensee reported that upon purchase,
compared to the emu’s siblings, the bird was smaller, had an abnormal beak, and was mildly unsteady on his feet. As the
emu developed more trouble walking and standing, the licensee took measures to modify the emu’s enclosure to stabilize
him and administered oral supplements such as vitamin B12, but did not consult his attending veterinarian in doing so.
On May 20, 2025, the licensee first contacted his attending veterinarian, who referred the licensee to an exotic animal
emergency hospital. The licensee instead brought the emu to the attending veterinarian the following day (May 21) where
emu was euthanatized due to the severity of his condition.
Belated communication with the attending veterinarian prevented timely veterinary care for the animal.
Each exhibitor shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include direct and frequent communication so
that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending
veterinarian.
Correct by this day forward: September 2, 2025.

The licensee did not maintain records of any animals acquired, sold, or disposed of in the past year.
Failure to maintain such records prevents tracing of animals and identification of trends in animal losses.
Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the following information
concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession.
Correct from this day forward: September 2, 2025.

The licensee reported that none of his four dogs (two dogs, two wolf-dog hybrids) received annual physical exams in the
past year. He could not recall the last time the dogs received a complete head-to-tail physical exam. There were no
examination records available at the facility.
Complete physical examinations provide important information to the veterinarian regarding an animal’s health status.
Without annual exams, there may be a delay in detecting diseases or injuries.
Each exhibitor must follow a program of veterinary care for dogs that includes complete physical examination from head
to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months.
Correct by: October 2, 2025.

The licensee is not following his veterinarian’s vaccination schedule for dogs. The licensee stated that his two wolf-dog
hybrids do not receive rabies vaccines. The program of veterinary care prescribes annual rabies vaccines to the wolf-dog
hybrids.
Failure to vaccinate dogs according to the veterinarian’s schedule can lead to contagious diseases.
Each exhibitor must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that includes vaccinations in accordance
with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian.
Correct by: October 2, 2025.

There were several cars (approximately 10) in various stages of repair on the site in which several birds on exhibit can
free roam. Car parts, a broken windshield with sharp edges, and many other equipment items are densely arranged in the
area and birds were seen roaming near these items during the inspection.
Materials such as broken glass, chemicals, and metals pose a toxin or injury risk to birds. Accumulations of equipment
can become an entrapment hazard for the animals and a breeding site for vermin.
Housing facilities must be kept neat and free of clutter, including equipment, furniture, and stored material.
Correct by: October 2, 2025.

The licensee is storing food for avian species improperly. Food was stored in an outdoor shed adjacent to excreta of the
free-roaming birds and flies. Bags of food were left open and on the floor in the shed. Cleaning supplies and insecticides
were stored adjacent to the open bags of food.
Improper storage of food can lead to contamination by chemicals, bacteria, or pests.
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects the
supplies from deterioration, spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and
away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Substances such as cleaning supplies and
disinfectants that are harmful to the birds but that are required for normal husbandry practices must not be stored in food
storage and preparation areas but may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas, provided that they are stored in properly
labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to the birds.
Correct by: September 16, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
A safe and effective method of pest control for the avian enclosures is not in place:
• Three wasp nests with several live wasps were seen in the ceiling of a shelter for 11 chickens. The licensee stated that
he used a wasp and hornet killer spray directly on the nests on them recently, but did not consult the attending
veterinarian before using it. The manufacturer’s instructions state “do not use this product in a way that will contact any
person or pet, either directly or through drift”. There were no identified health effects of the spray on the animals.
• Many flies were present in the area around the food storage shed and the adjacent bird shelter (the “sunroom”) which
appeared related to an abundance of excreta. A large fly strip was completely covered in flies.
Insect pests can cause sting or transmit disease to animals, or contaminate food.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects must be established and maintained so as to promote the health
and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other
pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact
surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does
not harm birds.
Correct by: October 2, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
According to the licensee, on May 21, 2025, a male emu was euthanized due to a severe unknown medical condition 
affecting his ability to walk. The licensee did not convey this condition to the attending veterinarian for approximately three 
months. 
 
A juvenile male emu, “Arnold”, was purchased in Mid-February, 2025. The licensee reported that upon purchase, 
compared to the emu’s siblings, the bird was smaller, had an abnormal beak, and was mildly unsteady on his feet. As the 
emu developed more trouble walking and standing, the licensee took measures to modify the emu’s enclosure to stabilize 
him and administered oral supplements such as vitamin B12, but did not consult his attending veterinarian in doing so.  
 
On May 20, 2025, the licensee first contacted his attending veterinarian, who referred the licensee to an exotic animal 
emergency hospital. The licensee instead brought the emu to the attending veterinarian the following day (May 21) where 
emu was euthanatized due to the severity of his condition. 
 
Belated communication with the attending veterinarian prevented timely veterinary care for the animal.  
 
Each exhibitor shall maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include direct and frequent communication so 
that timely and accurate information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being is conveyed to the attending 
veterinarian. 
 
Correct by this day forward: September 2, 2025. 
2.75(b)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
The licensee did not maintain records of any animals acquired, sold, or disposed of in the past year.  
 
Failure to maintain such records prevents tracing of animals and identification of trends in animal losses.

Every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records which fully and correctly disclose the following information 
concerning animals purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under 
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The 
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession. 
 
Correct from this day forward: September 2, 2025. 
3.13(a)(2) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee reported that none of his four dogs (two dogs, two wolf-dog hybrids) received annual physical exams in the 
past year. He could not recall the last time the dogs received a complete head-to-tail physical exam. There were no 
examination records available at the facility. 
 
Complete physical examinations provide important information to the veterinarian regarding an animal’s health status. 
Without annual exams, there may be a delay in detecting diseases or injuries.  
 
Each exhibitor must follow a program of veterinary care for dogs that includes complete physical examination from head 
to tail of each dog by the attending veterinarian not less than once every 12 months. 
 
Correct by: October 2, 2025. 
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The licensee is not following his veterinarian’s vaccination schedule for dogs. The licensee stated that his two wolf-dog 
hybrids do not receive rabies vaccines. The program of veterinary care prescribes annual rabies vaccines to the wolf-dog 
hybrids. 
 
Failure to vaccinate dogs according to the veterinarian’s schedule can lead to contagious diseases.  
 
Each exhibitor must follow an appropriate program of veterinary care for dogs that includes vaccinations in accordance 
with a schedule approved by the attending veterinarian. 
 
Correct by: October 2, 2025. 
3.150(b) 
   
Facilities, general. 
There were several cars (approximately 10) in various stages of repair on the site in which several birds on exhibit can 
free roam. Car parts, a broken windshield with sharp edges, and many other equipment items are densely arranged in the 
area and birds were seen roaming near these items during the inspection. 
 
Materials such as broken glass, chemicals, and metals pose a toxin or injury risk to birds. Accumulations of equipment

can become an entrapment hazard for the animals and a breeding site for vermin.  
 
Housing facilities must be kept neat and free of clutter, including equipment, furniture, and stored material.  
 
Correct by: October 2, 2025. 
3.150(e) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The licensee is storing food for avian species improperly. Food was stored in an outdoor shed adjacent to excreta of the 
free-roaming birds and flies. Bags of food were left open and on the floor in the shed. Cleaning supplies and insecticides 
were stored adjacent to the open bags of food.  
 
Improper storage of food can lead to contamination by chemicals, bacteria, or pests.  
 
Supplies of food, including food supplements, bedding, and substrate must be stored in a manner that protects the 
supplies from deterioration, spoilage, contamination, and vermin infestation. The supplies must be stored off the floor and 
away from the walls, to allow cleaning underneath and around the supplies. Substances such as cleaning supplies and

storage and preparation areas but may be stored in cabinets in the animal areas, provided that they are stored in properly 
labeled containers that are adequately secured to prevent potential harm to the birds.  
 
Correct by: September 16, 2025. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
A safe and effective method of pest control for the avian enclosures is not in place: 
 
• Three wasp nests with several live wasps were seen in the ceiling of a shelter for 11 chickens. The licensee stated that 
he used a wasp and hornet killer spray directly on the nests on them recently, but did not consult the attending 
veterinarian before using it. The manufacturer’s instructions state “do not use this product in a way that will contact any 
person or pet, either directly or through drift”. There were no identified health effects of the spray on the animals.  
• Many flies were present in the area around the food storage shed and the adjacent bird shelter (the “sunroom”) which 
appeared related to an abundance of excreta. A large fly strip was completely covered in flies.  
 
Insect pests can cause sting or transmit disease to animals, or contaminate food. 
 
A safe and effective program for the control of insects must be established and maintained so as to promote the health 
and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other 
pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact 
surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does 
not harm birds.

Correct by: October 2, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
